questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a recurrent rash that first appeared 1 year ago. He has multiple skin lesions on his legs, buttocks, and around his mouth. The rash tends to resolve spontaneously in one location before reappearing in another location a few days later. It begins with painless, reddish spots that gradually increase in size and then develop into painful and itchy blisters. The patient also reports having repeated bouts of diarrhea and has lost 10 kg (22 lb) over the past year. One year ago, the patient was diagnosed with major depressive syndrome and was started on fluoxetine. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows multiple crusty patches with central areas of bronze-colored induration and tender eruptive lesions with irregular borders on his legs, buttocks, and around his lips. Nikolsky sign is negative. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.2 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 88 μm3, and serum glucose is 210 mg/dL. A skin biopsy of the lesion shows epidermal necrosis. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Increased serum vasoactive intestinal polypeptide level
Villous atrophy in small bowel biopsy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antibodies against hemidesmosomes are seen in bullous pemphigoid (BP), a common bullous autoimmune disease in which Nikolsky sign is also negative. However, lesions in BP start as pruritic, urticarial lesions that develop into tense blisters. Moreover, BP most commonly occurs in individuals aged > 60 years and is not associated with hyperglycemia, chronic diarrhea, or anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Antiglutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies (anti-GAD antibodies) are found in patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus, which can also manifest with hyperglycemia, weight loss, and anemia. However, patients with type 1 diabetes do not present with necrolytic migratory erythema.

A rare, cutaneous complication of diabetes mellitus is necrobiosis lipoidica, in which histopathology would reveal a palisaded, granulomatous inflammation of the dermis and subcutaneous tissue.

C) CORRECT:

Increased fasting glucagon levels indicate a glucagonoma, a pancreatic α-cell neuroendocrine tumor. Excess glucagon increases gluconeogenesis and inhibits glycolysis, causing hyperglycemia and/or mild diabetes. Anemia may be a result of chronic illness or directly related to the inhibitory effect of glucagon on erythropoiesis. Patients with glucagonoma can also present with neuropsychiatric symptoms (e.g., depression, dementia, ataxia). NME is a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with tumors that secrete glucagon. Patients with suspected glucagonoma should undergo imaging (CT and/or MRI) to determine the location and size of the tumor and assess for possible metastases.
Image Description:

Feet of a patient with pancreatic glucagonoma

An annular erythema consisting of ring-shaped, linear, bronze-colored areas as well as red patches is visible. The surface of the erythema crusts and has formed macules and erosions.

These lesions are suggestive of necrolytic migratory erythema associated with pancreatic glucagonoma. They can be differentiated from acrodermatitis enteropathica by the measurement of plasma zinc levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased levels of vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP) are seen in patients with VIPoma, which commonly manifests with chronic watery diarrhea and associated weight loss. In addition, patients typically have achlorhydria, hypokalemia, and hyperglycemia. However, necrolytic migratory erythema is not seen in patients with VIPoma and suggests another diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibodies against desmoglein 1 and 3 are present in pemphigus vulgaris, a rare autoimmune disease that causes multiple blistering lesions. However, the Nikolsky sign is positive in pemphigus vulgaris and the skin lesions are not migratory. Furthermore, patients with pemphigus vulgaris do not have hyperglycemia, chronic diarrhea, or weight loss.
Image Description:

Flaccid lesions with white plaques are visible on the oral mucosa. The plaque can be scraped off, causing deep red erosions.

These findings are consistent with pemphigus vulgaris.

F) INCORRECT:

Severely decreased serum zinc levels are typically found in zinc uptake deficiency (e.g., in acrodermatitis enteropathica), which can also manifest with chronic diarrhea and anemia. Skin lesions that appear similar to necrolytic migratory erythema can be present, however, lesions mainly appear around orifices (e.g., perioral) and are vesicular, without a central area of induration. Moreover, neither the hereditary form (manifests at a young age with failure to thrive) nor the acquired form (secondary to celiac disease or inflammatory bowel disease) is associated with hyperglycemia. Furthermore, this patient lacks other symptoms of zinc deficiency, such as impaired taste, hypogonadism, or night blindness.

G) INCORRECT:

Villous atrophy is typically seen in celiac disease (CD), a malabsorptive condition that can cause chronic diarrhea and anemia. CD can manifest with a pruritic rash known as dermatitis herpetiformis. However, lesions are usually bilateral and symmetric, not migratory. Moreover, the rash is characterized by tense, grouped subepidermal vesicles, papules, and/or bullae. Patients with CD commonly present with abdominal cramps and depression. Hyperglycemia is not a typical finding.
questions.hint: This patient's multiple lesions that developed into painful and pruritic crusty patches with areas of bronze-colored induration, and with a centrifugal distribution, are characteristic of necrolytic migratory erythema (NME). Lesions in NME tend to resolve and then reappear in a different location. NME, anemia, hyperglycemia, and chronic diarrhea (with associated weight loss) are characteristic symptoms of a disease process that affects the pancreas.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician because of multiple, ulcerative skin lesions over various parts of her body that first appeared 6 months ago. They occur episodically and usually start as reddish spots, which then expand in size and ulcerate over the next ten days. They resolve spontaneously and reappear at another location a few days later. Over the past 6 months, she has had multiple episodes of diarrhea. She has had an 8-kg (18-lb) weight loss during this period and feels tired constantly. She has not had a fever. She was treated for deep venous thrombosis 3 years ago and took medication for 6 months after the episode. She appears pale. Her vital signs are within normal limits. She has multiple, tender, ulcerative skin lesions on her legs and buttocks. Her hemoglobin is 9.6 mg/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 82 μm3, and fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 154 mg/dL. Her serum glucagon concentration is elevated. Abdominal ultrasonography reveals a 5.6-cm, well-demarcated, hypoechoic mass in the pancreatic body and multiple, small masses in the liver of variable echogenicity. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Resection of the distal portion of the pancreas is the definitive treatment for glucagonoma that is strictly localized to the pancreas and not metastasized. In localized disease, resection can lead to rapid resolution of symptoms. However, localized glucagonoma is rare and this patient already shows features that are highly suspicious for metastatic disease (liver lesions on ultrasound), which requires further evaluation before determining a surgical treatment option. Furthermore, even if the disease is localized, this patient's symptoms and hyperglycemia should be resolved before surgery.

B) INCORRECT:

Zinc deficiency, which is commonly associated with malabsorptive syndromes (e.g., Crohn disease, celiac disease), can manifest with chronic diarrhea, anemia, and skin lesions (especially perioral blistering lesions). Although these lesions are very similar to necrolytic migratory erythema, they do not migrate. Also, zinc deficiency is not associated with hyperglycemia and it does not explain the presence of a pancreatic mass.

C) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic ultrasound provides excellent spatial resolution (up to 2–3 mm), allowing detection of very small tumors and providing more accurate information on the local disease extent. However, endoscopic ultrasound only plays a minor role in the diagnosis of glucagonoma since it is primarily detected by the use of hormonal assays and CT or MRI imaging.

D) INCORRECT:

CA 19-9 is a tumor marker that can be useful in the evaluation of exocrine pancreatic cancer. Since pancreatic cancer is a diagnosis that always needs histologic confirmation, tumor markers should not be routinely obtained for cancer screening or diagnosis. Once a definitive diagnosis of pancreatic cancer is established, CA 19-9 can be used later as a marker for prognosis and treatment response.

E) CORRECT:

Octreotide, a somatostatin analog, reduces the secretion of glucagon to control the symptoms resulting from hypersecretion of glucagon (hyperglycemia, diarrhea, necrolytic migratory erythema, neurologic symptoms). In addition to supportive care (e.g., control of hyperglycemia), octreotide is the preferred initial therapy to bring these symptoms under rapid control.

F) INCORRECT:

Glycated hemoglobin (HbA1C) is used as a marker to monitor glucose control in patients with diabetes who are expected to have long-term impairment of glucose tolerance (such as insulin deficiency or resistance). HbA1C is not useful in patients who can be offered definitive causative treatment for secondary hyperglycemia.
questions.hint: Necrolytic migratory erythema, normocytic normochromic anemia, chronic diarrhea, and elevated glucose levels are characteristic clinical features of glucagonoma. The diagnosis is confirmed by elevated serum glucagon levels. An abdominal ultrasound showing masses in the pancreas and liver is likely indicative of metastatic disease.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of diarrhea. During this period, he has had about 10 bowel movements per day. He states that his stools are light brown and watery, with no blood or mucus. He also reports mild abdominal pain and nausea. Over the past year, he has had 6 episodes of diarrhea that lasted several days and resolved spontaneously. Over this time, he also noticed frequent episodes of reddening in his face and neck. He returned from a 10-day trip to Nigeria 3 weeks ago. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 13 years. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes. The abdomen is tender with no rebound or guarding. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:


Na+

136 mEq/L


Cl-

94 mEq/L


K+

2.3 mEq/L


HCO3-

22 mEq/L


Mg2+

1.7 mEq/L


Ca2+

12.3 mg/dL


Glucose (fasting)
169 mg/dL


Nasogastric tube aspiration reveals significantly decreased gastric acid production. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Transmural inflammation of the intestinal walls

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Systemic mastocytosis could cause significant diarrhea, abdominal pain, nausea, and cutaneous flushing. The excessive accumulation of mast cells seen in this disease can localize to specific organs, like the intestine, where synchronous activation leads to an excessive release of mast cell mediators, such as histamine, prostaglandins, proteases, and various cytokines. The skin is often involved and patients typically report pruritus and urticaria. However, this rare disease would not cause the laboratory abnormalities or achlorhydria/hypochlorhydria seen in this patient and is, therefore, an unlikely cause of his symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

Elevated serum vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) concentration (> 75 pg/mL) is found in patients with VIPoma. Excessive release of VIP in patients with this condition increases relaxation of gastric and intestinal smooth muscles and causes unregulated fluid and electrolyte secretion, leading to secretory tea-colored diarrhea, along with the resulting dehydration, hypochloremia, and hypokalemia. VIP also inhibits gastric acid secretion, increases bone resorption, and stimulates glycogenolysis, leading to achlorhydria/hypochlorhydria, hypercalcemia, and hyperglycemia, respectively. The cutaneous flushing seen in this patient is a result of VIP-induced vasodilation; this finding is seen in approximately 20% of patients with VIPoma.

The primary tumor is most frequently found in the pancreas and can be localized with an abdominal CT scan.

C) INCORRECT:

Carcinoid syndrome due to a serotonin-producing carcinoid tumor can also manifest with diarrhea, tachycardia, and flushing, making it an important differential diagnosis. However, this patient lacks the asthma-like attacks (dyspnea and wheezing) and valvular lesions (e.g., tricuspid regurgitation) that are often seen in carcinoid syndrome. Additionally, carcinoid syndrome would not explain this patient's abnormal laboratory values or his achlorhydria/hypochlorhydria.

D) INCORRECT:

Vibrio cholerae could explain this patient's watery diarrhea, and he did recently travel to an endemic country. However, patients infected with Vibrio cholerae typically have vomiting, and a recent infection would not explain his previous history of chronic diarrhea and flushing, nor his decreased gastric acid output.

E) INCORRECT:

Transmural inflammation of the intestinal wall is characteristic of Crohn disease (CD). This patient is a smoker, which is a known risk factor for CD. He also presents with diffuse abdominal pain, but the abdominal pain that is seen in CD typically appears in the right lower quadrant due to terminal ileitis. Furthermore, CD usually manifests with signs of malabsorption such as weight loss and anemia. Extraintestinal symptoms like erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosum, and/or uveitis may also be present. More importantly, CD would not explain this patient's laboratory abnormalities, cutaneous flushing, or achlorhydria.
questions.hint: This patient describes a year-long history of diarrheal episodes, recently characterized by light brown, watery bowel movements, with mild abdominal pain and episodic cutaneous flushing. Together with hypokalemia, hypercalcemia, hyperglycemia, and achlorhydria/hypochlorhydria, this presentation is consistent with a specific neuroendocrine tumor.

questions.text: A previously healthy 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of recurrent abdominal pain, foul-smelling, greasy stools, and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss despite no change in appetite. Physical examination shows pain on palpation of the right upper quadrant. His fasting serum glucose concentration is 186 mg/dL. Abdominal ultrasound shows multiple round, echogenic foci within the gallbladder lumen with prominent posterior acoustic shadowing. The serum concentration of which of the following substances is most likely to be increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Somatostatin is likely to be increased in this patient, who has the typical clinical findings of somatostatinoma, illustrating the hormone's primarily inhibitory effects. Glucose intolerance and diabetes mellitus result from the inhibition of insulin secretion. Diarrhea and steatorrhea occur due to inhibition of pancreatic enzymes and bicarbonate secretion, leading to lipid malabsorption. Finally, the inhibition of cholecystokinin release, which reduces gallbladder contractility and leads to bile stasis, causes cholelithiasis.

See “Overview of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors” table.

B) INCORRECT:

Glucagon levels would be elevated if this patient had glucagonoma. Glucagonoma typically presents with glucose intolerance/diabetes mellitus, diarrhea, and weight loss, which are present here. However, over 70% of patients with glucagonoma also present with necrolytic migratory erythema, which this patient does not have. In addition, cholelithiasis would not be expected in a glucagonoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Serotonin levels are elevated in carcinoid tumors, which can present with diarrhea and weight loss, which are seen here, in addition to carcinoid syndrome (in tumors located outside the GI tract). However, carcinoid tumors are not typically associated with cholelithiasis or hyperglycemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Gastrin levels would be elevated in Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (gastrinoma). Gastrinoma is characterized by gastric acid hypersecretion, which leads to therapy-resistant peptic ulcer disease (PUD) and diarrhea. Although this patient has diarrhea and recurrent abdominal pain, which could be due to PUD, he also presents with fasting hyperglycemia and cholelithiasis, which would not be expected in gastrinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Insulin levels are elevated in insulinoma, which would present with weight gain and recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia. In contrast, this patient has fasting hyperglycemia and weight loss. Insulinoma would also not explain his cholelithiasis or steatorrhea.

F) INCORRECT:

Vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) levels are elevated in VIPomas, which typically present with WDHA syndrome. WDHA syndrome does involve diarrhea. However, the diarrhea in WDHA syndrome is usually watery (due to excess secretion of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen) rather than greasy and foul-smelling (steatorrhea due to malabsorption). Patients with WDHA syndrome also have hypokalemia and achlorhydria, neither of which is described here. VIPomas are not associated with significant weight loss, hyperglycemia, or cholelithiasis.
questions.hint: Abdominal pain and weight loss combined with the triad of glucose intolerance (fasting hyperglycemia), cholelithiasis, and steatorrhea should raise concern for a tumor arising from the pancreatic δ cells (D cells).

questions.text:
A 48-year old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of an 8-month history of fatigue and profuse, watery, odorless diarrhea. He reports that he has had a 10.5-kg (23-lb) weight loss during this time. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor and poor skin turgor. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
9.8 g/dl


Serum



Glucose (fasting)
130 mg/dl


K+

2.5 mEq/L


Ca2+

12 mg/dl


A CT scan of the abdomen with contrast shows a 3.0 × 3.2 × 4.4 cm, well-defined, enhancing lesion in the pancreatic tail. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Achlorhydria would most likely be seen on further evaluation of this patient with a VIPoma. VIPomas are usually solitary and occur in the pancreatic tail. VIPoma can occur sporadically (> 95% of cases) or as part of the MEN1. VIPoma syndrome is caused by the excessive secretion of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) by the tumor. This results in excess fluid and electrolyte secretion into the lumen, leading to secretory diarrhea and hypokalemia. VIP also inhibits gastric acid secretion, leading to achlorhydria. Reduced gastric acid can lead to iron and vitamin B12 malabsorption, which can result in anemia, as seen in this patient. The hyperglycemia often noted in patients with WDHA syndrome is secondary to enhanced glycogenolysis caused by the effect of high portal vein VIP signaling on the liver.

B) INCORRECT:

Cholelithiasis is a finding associated with somatostatinomas, which would arise in the pancreas and can present with weight loss, diarrhea, and glucose intolerance. However, diarrhea in a patient with a somatostatinoma is typically caused by fat malabsorption. Therefore, stools would be foul-smelling (steatorrhea), unlike the odorless watery diarrhea in this patient. Moreover, somatostatinomas are among the least common pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors in patients with MEN1 syndrome. They are more commonly associated with neurofibromatosis type I (von Recklinghausen disease).

C) INCORRECT:

Hyperinsulinemia can be seen in the case of insulinomas, which would arise in the pancreas and can occur as a part of MEN1 syndrome. However, insulinomas would cause recurrent hypoglycemia and patients present with Whipple's triad. Diarrhea and anemia would not be expected with an insulinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Peptic ulcers are seen in patients with a gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome) due to high levels of gastrin causing increased gastric acid secretion. Gastrinomas often arise in the pancreas, can cause diarrhea as well as anemia (due to chronic GI bleeding from peptic ulcers), and can occur a part of MEN1 syndrome. However, gastrinomas have no effect on blood glucose levels.

E) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid insufficiency can be seen in carcinoid syndrome, which is caused by carcinoid tumors. This patient's profuse watery diarrhea is consistent with carcinoid syndrome. However, carcinoid tumors are most commonly found in the appendix, terminal ileum, or bronchi, unlike the pancreatic mass in this patient, and other features characteristic of carcinoid syndrome (e.g., flushing, wheezing) are not present in this case.

F) INCORRECT:

Deep vein thrombosis can be associated with a glucagonoma, which most commonly occurs as part of MEN1 syndrome. Although patients may also present with diarrhea, weight loss, and hyperglycemia, glucagonomas are typically associated with necrolytic migratory erythema (seen in 70% of patients). Neuropsychiatric symptoms may also occur. Other symptoms include abdominal pain and angular cheilitis.

G) INCORRECT:

Episodic hypertension is associated with pheochromocytomas. Pheochromocytoma can occur in conjunction with hypercalcemia in patients with MEN2A. Hyperglycemia and hypokalemia can also occur in patients with pheochromocytoma due to the effects of catecholamines. However, a pheochromocytoma arises in the adrenal medulla, not the pancreas. Moreover, patients with a pheochromocytoma typically have symptoms such as episodic headaches, diaphoresis, and palpitations. Diarrhea is not a clinical feature of pheochromocytoma.
questions.hint: Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and a pancreatic mass are pathognomonic of a rare type of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor. The hypercalcemia in this patient is most likely due to coexistent hyperparathyroidism of multiple endocrine neoplasia 1 syndrome (MEN1).

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman has a 6 month history of episodic skin lesions. The lesions start as reddish spots, then expand, ulcerate, and heal spontaneously before reappearing elsewhere. She has had multiple episodes of diarrhea and an 8-kg (18-lb) weight loss during this period. She was treated for deep venous thrombosis 3 years ago. She has multiple, tender, ulcerative skin lesions on her legs and buttocks. Her hemoglobin is 9.6 mg/dL, fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 154 mg/dL, and serum glucagon concentration is elevated. Abdominal ultrasonography reveals a 5.6-cm, well-demarcated, hypoechoic mass in the pancreatic body and multiple, small masses in the liver of variable echogenicity. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Resection of the distal portion of the pancreas is the definitive treatment for glucagonoma that is strictly localized to the pancreas and not metastasized. In localized disease, resection can lead to rapid resolution of symptoms. However, localized glucagonoma is rare and this patient already shows features that are highly suspicious for metastatic disease (liver lesions on ultrasound), which requires further evaluation before determining a surgical treatment option. Furthermore, even if the disease is localized, this patient's symptoms and hyperglycemia should be resolved before surgery.

B) INCORRECT:

Zinc deficiency, which is commonly associated with malabsorptive syndromes (e.g., Crohn disease, celiac disease), can manifest with chronic diarrhea and skin lesions (especially perioral blistering lesions). Although these lesions are very similar to necrolytic migratory erythema, they do not migrate. Also, zinc deficiency is not associated with hyperglycemia and it does not explain the presence of a pancreatic mass.

C) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic ultrasound provides excellent spatial resolution (up to 2–3 mm), allowing detection of very small tumors and providing more accurate information on the local disease extent. However, endoscopic ultrasound only plays a minor role in the diagnosis of glucagonoma since it is primarily detected by the use of hormonal assays and CT or MRI imaging.

D) CORRECT:

Octreotide, a somatostatin analog, reduces the secretion of glucagon to control the symptoms resulting from hypersecretion of glucagon (hyperglycemia, diarrhea, necrolytic migratory erythema, neurologic symptoms). In addition to supportive care (e.g., control of hyperglycemia), octreotide is the preferred initial therapy to bring these symptoms under rapid control.

E) INCORRECT:

Glycated hemoglobin (HbA1C) is used as a marker to monitor glucose control in patients with diabetes who are expected to have long-term impairment of glucose tolerance (such as insulin deficiency or resistance). HbA1C is not useful in patients who can be offered definitive causative treatment for secondary hyperglycemia.
questions.hint: Necrolytic migratory erythema, chronic diarrhea, and elevated glucose levels are characteristic clinical features of glucagonoma. The diagnosis is confirmed by elevated serum glucagon levels. An abdominal ultrasound showing masses in the pancreas and liver is likely indicative of metastatic disease.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old man comes to your clinic with fatigue, recurrent diarrhea, and an 8-kg weight loss over the past 6 months. He reports a 4-month history of recurrent blistering rashes on various parts of his body that develop into pruritic, crusty lesions before resolving on their own. On examination, there are scaly lesions in different stages of healing with central, bronze-colored induration around the mouth, perineum, and lower extremities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin (Hgb), blood
101 g/L (125–170)


Mean corpuscular volume (MCV), blood
85 fL (80–100)


Mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH), blood
30.0 pg (27–34)


Glucose, random, blood
13.1 mmol/L (4.0–11.0)


Abdominal ultrasonography reveals a 3-cm solid mass in the upper abdomen. Which one of the following tumors is most likely responsible for this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gastrinomas, which are functional neuroendocrine tumors derived from gastric G-cells, secrete gastrin and can manifest with weight loss and recurrent diarrhea. However, these tumors are not associated with hyperglycemia or necrolytic migratory erythema. In addition, this patient lacks other typical manifestations of a gastrinoma, including abdominal pain and dyspepsia.

B) INCORRECT:

Somatostatinomas, which are functional neuroendocrine tumors derived from pancreatic δ-cells, secrete somatostatin and can manifest with weight loss and glucose intolerance. However, these tumors are not associated with necrolytic migratory erythema. In addition, this patient lacks other typical manifestations of a somatostatinoma, including abdominal pain, steatorrhea, and cholelithiasis.

C) INCORRECT:

Carcinoid tumors, which are functional neuroendocrine tumors derived from enterochromaffin cells, produce serotonin and can manifest with weight loss and recurrent diarrhea. These tumors are associated with skin lesions caused by niacin deficiency (e.g., casal necklace), but they are not associated with necrolytic migratory erythema. In addition, this patient lacks other typical manifestations of a carcinoid tumor, including flushing and wheezing.

D) INCORRECT:

Insulinomas, which are functional neuroendocrine tumors derived from pancreatic β-cells, produce insulin and manifest with weight gain (not weight loss) and hypoglycemia (not hyperglycemia). Moreover, they are not associated with necrolytic migratory erythema.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has a glucagonoma, a functional neuroendocrine tumor derived from pancreatic α-cells. These tumors secrete glucagon, which increases gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis and thus results in hyperglycemia. Other features of glucagonoma include chronic diarrhea, weight loss, neuropsychiatric symptoms (e.g., depression, dementia, ataxia), deep vein thrombosis, normocytic anemia (due to anemia of chronic disease and the inhibitory effect of glucagon on erythropoiesis), and necrolytic migratory erythema. The pathophysiology that underlies the development of necrolytic migratory erythema is not well understood, but it may be related to direct action of glucagon on the skin, protein deficiency (because glucagon causes proteolysis), and/or a deficiency of zinc and fatty acids due to chronic diarrhea.

See “Overview of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors” table.

Key learning point: Glucagonoma is a pancreatic alpha-cell tumor that causes hyperglycemia, weight loss, normocytic anemia, and necrolytic migratory erythema due to excess glucagon secretion.
Image Description:

Feet of a patient with pancreatic glucagonoma

An annular erythema consisting of ring-shaped, linear, bronze-colored areas as well as red patches is visible. The surface of the erythema crusts and has formed macules and erosions.

These lesions are suggestive of necrolytic migratory erythema associated with pancreatic glucagonoma. They can be differentiated from acrodermatitis enteropathica by the measurement of plasma zinc levels.
questions.hint: This patient's rash, known as necrolytic migratory erythema, is strongly associated with his underlying tumor.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of profuse watery diarrhea, progressive weakness, and 6.8-kg (15-lb) weight loss. She reports feeling dizzy upon standing and has had decreased appetite. Physical examination shows dehydration, muscle weakness, and hypotension. Laboratory results show glucose 180 mg/dL, potassium 2.8 mEq/L, and bicarbonate 18 mEq/L. Gastric pH testing shows achlorhydria. What is the most appropriate initial management?

choices.text: Intravenous fluid resuscitation and electrolyte replacement

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endoscopy is not indicated in this patient's presentation of secretory diarrhea with achlorhydria. The clinical picture suggests a hormonal cause rather than a structural gastrointestinal pathology that requires urgent visualization.

B) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics may be appropriate for infectious gastroenteritis. This patient's chronicity of symptoms, achlorhydria, and electrolyte abnormalities suggest secretory diarrhea from a neuroendocrine tumor. Another management step is indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

While octreotide is used to treat VIPoma, another step in management should be performed first.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria (WDHA syndrome), which suggests a VIPoma. The immediate priority is stabilization with aggressive fluid resuscitation and correction of severe hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis before pursuing a diagnostic workup.

E) INCORRECT:

Proton pump inhibitors are contraindicated in achlorhydria. They worsen gastric acid suppression and may exacerbate nutrient malabsorption.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 6-week history of profuse watery diarrhea, 5.4-kg (12-lb) weight loss, and progressive weakness. She reports no fever, blood in the stool, or recent antibiotic use. Physical examination shows dehydration and muscle weakness. Initial laboratory studies show serum potassium of 2.8 mEq/L, glucose of 180 mg/dL, and normal inflammatory markers. Stool volume is measured at 900 mL over 8 hours. Given her clinical presentation and laboratory findings, what is the most appropriate next diagnostic study?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with hyperglycemia and weight loss in combination with watery (secretory) diarrhea (> 700 mL/day), hypokalemia, and achlorhydria (WDHA syndrome), which is the triad of classic clinical features of VIPoma, a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor. Measurement of serum vasoactive intestinal polypeptide levels > 75 pg/mL is the specific diagnostic test for VIPoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy with biopsy is not indicated for secretory diarrhea with systemic metabolic effects. High-volume watery diarrhea with hypokalemia and hyperglycemia suggests a hormone-secreting tumor rather than inflammatory or structural bowel disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Chromogranin A is a general neuroendocrine tumor marker that lacks specificity for VIPoma diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Thyroid function tests are not indicated, as hyperthyroidism typically manifests with additional symptoms like palpitations, tremor, and heat intolerance. High-volume watery diarrhea with severe hypokalemia and hyperglycemia is more consistent with another diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Stool osmotic gap calculation helps differentiate secretory from osmotic diarrhea but does not identify the specific underlying neuroendocrine tumor. This patient's clinical presentation suggests secretory diarrhea, but specific hormone levels are needed to confirm the diagnosis of VIPoma and guide treatment.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 3-month history of voluminous watery diarrhea, significant weight loss, and weakness. Vital signs are BP, 88/52; P, 118; T, 37.2°C (99.0°F). Laboratory results show serum potassium 2.1 mEq/L, serum glucose 180 mg/dL, and serum vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) concentration 120 pg/mL. CT imaging shows a 4-cm pancreatic mass with liver metastases. What is the most appropriate initial pharmacological management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Proton pump inhibitors are not indicated for VIPomas, which cause achlorhydria due to VIP-induced inhibition of gastric acid production. Omeprazole does not address the underlying hormone excess.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Octreotide is the most appropriate initial pharmacological management for VIPoma because it directly inhibits VIP secretion, addressing the underlying cause of the secretory diarrhea, dehydration, and electrolyte abnormalities. Metastases indicate inoperable disease, making octreotide the initial treatment to control a life-threatening hormone excess and stabilize this patient's condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Loperamide is used to treat diarrhea caused by increased motility but is ineffective for secretory diarrhea caused by VIP excess. The massive fluid losses in VIPoma are due to VIP-induced cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) activity. Antimotility agents do not address the secretory mechanism.

D) INCORRECT:

While chemotherapy may be considered for metastatic pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors, it is not the initial priority. Chemotherapy is a longer-term oncological consideration after initial stabilization.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's hyperglycemia is secondary to VIP excess stimulating glycogenolysis. Insulin does not address the primary pathophysiology causing this patient's life-threatening fluid and electrolyte losses.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to the ED with abdominal pain and is found to have a 2-cm pancreatic mass on CT. He reports a 4-month history of intermittent abdominal pain, diarrhea, and 10-pound weight loss. Which clinical finding would most strongly suggest this tumor is a gastrinoma?

choices.text: Multiple peptic ulcers in unusual locations

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic diarrhea with steatorrhea can occur with multiple pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors, including gastrinoma and somatostatinoma, making this finding non-specific for gastrinoma diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Recurrent hypoglycemic episodes are characteristic of insulinoma, which secretes excess insulin causing endogenous hyperinsulinism and Whipple triad. Gastrinomas do not affect blood glucose levels.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – Multiple peptic ulcers in unusual locations such as the distal duodenum or jejunum are highly characteristic of gastrinoma. This finding, along with therapy-resistant ulcer disease, strongly suggests Zollinger-Ellison syndrome caused by excess gastrin secretion.

D) INCORRECT:

Profuse watery diarrhea with hypokalemia describes WDHA syndrome, characteristic of VIPoma. VIP causes secretory diarrhea exceeding 700 mL daily with associated electrolyte disturbances and achlorhydria.

E) INCORRECT:

Hyperglycemia with skin rash describes glucagonoma, which causes diabetes and necrolytic migratory erythema. The characteristic rash presents as spreading erythema that becomes crusty with bronze-colored induration.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of an itchy, blistering rash on her face, perineum, and thighs. She also reports a 15-lb unintentional weight loss and was recently diagnosed with diabetes mellitus. Physical examination reveals erythematous plaques with central clearing, crusting, and superficial erosions. An excess of the hormone responsible for this patient's condition most directly causes which of the following physiologic effects?

choices.text: Increased gastric acid secretion by parietal cells
Enhanced glucose uptake by peripheral tissues
Stimulation of intestinal water and electrolyte secretion
Inhibition of gastrin and cholecystokinin release

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This is the physiologic effect of gastrin, a hormone secreted in excess by a gastrinoma in Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. This condition would present with signs and symptoms of severe peptic ulcer disease, such as abdominal pain and gastrointestinal bleeding, rather than the characteristic rash and new-onset diabetes seen in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation of necrolytic migratory erythema, weight loss, and new-onset diabetes mellitus is the classic triad for a glucagonoma, a rare neuroendocrine tumor of pancreatic alpha cells. Glucagonomas secrete excessive amounts of glucagon, a hormone that counteracts the effects of insulin. Glucagon's primary site of action is the liver, where it stimulates glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. These actions lead to a massive overproduction of glucose by the liver, resulting in hyperglycemia and secondary diabetes mellitus seen in this patient. The catabolic state induced by high glucagon levels also contributes to significant weight loss.

C) INCORRECT:

This describes the primary action of insulin, not glucagon. While the patient has diabetes, a disorder of glucose metabolism, her condition is caused by severe hyperglycemia from glucagon excess, which overwhelms the body's insulin response. The underlying pathophysiology is excessive glucose production by the liver, not increased glucose uptake by tissues like muscle and fat.

D) INCORRECT:

This is the characteristic effect of Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide (VIP), which is overproduced in a VIPoma. While this is another type of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor, it typically presents with profuse, watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria (WDHA syndrome). This patient's clinical picture is dominated by dermatologic and metabolic findings, not gastrointestinal fluid losses.

E) INCORRECT:

This inhibitory effect is characteristic of somatostatin, which is secreted by a somatostatinoma. This rare tumor can cause a triad of diabetes, cholelithiasis, and steatorrhea due to its widespread inhibitory actions on other hormones and exocrine functions. However, it is not associated with the necrolytic migratory erythema rash seen in this case.
questions.hint: The classic rash described, known as necrolytic migratory erythema, combined with new-onset diabetes and weight loss, points to a specific pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with a painful, spreading rash for the past four months. The rash fluctuates in severity but has worsened recently. She also reports a 7-kg (15 lb) unintentional weight loss over the same period and was recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Physical examination shows annular erythematous plaques with central bullae, erosions, and crusting in the perineum and on her lower extremities. Her tongue appears smooth and red. Laboratory studies show a glucose level of 190 mg/dL and a markedly elevated serum glucagon level. An abdominal CT confirms a 4-cm mass in the tail of the pancreas. Which of the following interventions will most rapidly improve her skin condition?

choices.text: Surgical resection of the pancreatic mass

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical corticosteroids are often used to treat inflammatory dermatoses. While they may provide minor, temporary relief of local skin inflammation, they do not address the systemic, metabolic cause of necrolytic migratory erythema, which is driven by hyperglucagonemia. Therefore, this would not lead to significant or rapid improvement of the overall condition.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has hyperglycemia secondary to the glucagonoma, and managing her diabetes is an important part of her care. However, insulin therapy only counteracts glucagon's effect on blood glucose; it does not inhibit glucagon secretion from the tumor or reverse the catabolic state and amino acid deficiencies responsible for the characteristic rash.

C) INCORRECT:

Surgical resection is the only curative treatment for localized glucagonoma and will ultimately resolve the skin condition. However, it is not the intervention that will most rapidly improve the rash. Patients are typically stabilized pre-operatively to improve their nutritional status and skin integrity, which are compromised by the severe catabolic state induced by the tumor.

D) INCORRECT:

Zinc deficiency can be associated with glucagonoma syndrome and may contribute to the skin manifestations. While supplementation can be a helpful adjunctive therapy, it does not address the primary driver of the rash, which is the extreme hyperglucagonemia. Therefore, it would not be the most rapidly effective intervention.

E) CORRECT:

Octreotide, a long-acting somatostatin analogue, directly inhibits the secretion of glucagon from the glucagonoma. This patient's skin findings are caused by the catabolic effects of extremely high glucagon levels, leading to hypoaminoacidemia. By rapidly lowering serum glucagon, it addresses the underlying pathophysiology of the rash, leading to rapid clinical improvement. It is the primary medical therapy used to control symptoms pre-operatively or in patients with unresectable or metastatic disease. Another vital component is nutritional support with amino acid infusions.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of necrolytic migratory erythema, new-onset diabetes, weight loss, and glossitis is classic for glucagonoma.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue, recurrent diarrhea, and an 8-kg (18-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. He has a 4-month history of recurrent blistering rashes on different parts of his body that grow and develop into pruritic, crusty lesions before resolving spontaneously. Physical examination shows scaly lesions in different phases of healing with central, bronze-colored induration around the mouth, perineum, and lower extremities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.1 mg/dL


Mean corpuscular volume
85 μm3



Mean corpuscular hemoglobin
30.0 pg/cell


Serum



Glucose
236 mg/dL


Abdominal ultrasonography shows a 3-cm, solid mass located in the upper abdomen. This patient's mass is most likely derived from which of the following types of cells?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carcinoid tumors, which are functional neuroendocrine tumors derived from enterochromaffin cells, produce serotonin and can manifest with weight loss and recurrent diarrhea. These tumors are associated with skin lesions caused by niacin deficiency (e.g., casal necklace), but they are not associated with necrolytic migratory erythema. In addition, this patient lacks other typical manifestations of a carcinoid tumor, including flushing and wheezing.
Image Description:

There are symmetrical, hyperpigmented, hyperkeratotic plaques on sun-exposed areas of the chest (Casal necklace), shoulders, face, hands, and arms.

This is the typical dermatological manifestation of pellagra. Dermatitis is one of the “4 D's of pellagra” alongside diarrhea, dementia, and death.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has a glucagonoma, a functional neuroendocrine tumor derived from pancreatic α-cells. These tumors secrete glucagon, which increases gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis and thus results in hyperglycemia. Other features of glucagonoma include chronic diarrhea, weight loss, neuropsychiatric symptoms (e.g., depression, dementia, ataxia), deep vein thrombosis, normocytic anemia (due to anemia of chronic disease and the inhibitory effect of glucagon on erythropoiesis), and necrolytic migratory erythema. The pathophysiology that underlies the development of necrolytic migratory erythema is not well understood, but it may be related to direct action of glucagon on the skin, protein deficiency (because glucagon causes proteolysis), and/or a deficiency of zinc and fatty acids due to chronic diarrhea.

See “Overview of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors” table.
Image Description:

Feet of a patient with pancreatic glucagonoma

An annular erythema consisting of ring-shaped, linear, bronze-colored areas as well as red patches is visible. The surface of the erythema crusts and has formed macules and erosions.

These lesions are suggestive of necrolytic migratory erythema associated with pancreatic glucagonoma. They can be differentiated from acrodermatitis enteropathica by the measurement of plasma zinc levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Insulinomas, which are functional neuroendocrine tumors derived from pancreatic β-cells, produce insulin and manifest with weight gain (not weight loss) and hypoglycemia (not hyperglycemia). Moreover, they are not associated with necrolytic migratory erythema.

D) INCORRECT:

Somatostatinomas, which are functional neuroendocrine tumors derived from pancreatic δ-cells, secrete somatostatin and can manifest with weight loss and glucose intolerance. However, these tumors are not associated with necrolytic migratory erythema. In addition, this patient lacks other typical manifestations of a somatostatinoma, including abdominal pain, steatorrhea, and cholelithiasis.

E) INCORRECT:

Gastrinomas, which are functional neuroendocrine tumors derived from gastric G-cells, secrete gastrin and can manifest with weight loss and recurrent diarrhea. However, these tumors are not associated with hyperglycemia or necrolytic migratory erythema. In addition, this patient lacks other typical manifestations of a gastrinoma, including abdominal pain and dyspepsia.
questions.hint: This patient's rash, known as necrolytic migratory erythema, is strongly associated with his underlying tumor.

questions.text:

Serum
